In public, Volcker was confident, but in private, less confident.

Did you ever have doubts in there?
I never had a doubt in my life (laughter).
Of course - of course - of course you worry.
He worried.
Volcker mentioned those Robert Krulwich stories, said they brightened his day.
This guy Robert Krulwich, yes, Robert Krulwich would cheer me up.
(Laughter) It's true, no question about it.
In the textbooks, once you stop printing so much money inflation should go away.
But it was taking a long time.
One reason it was taking so long - people did not believe inflation would go down.
Part of the problem was in our heads.
If people believe there's going to be inflation, then they go to their bosses and they say, you got to give me a raise to keep up with inflation.
Employers say, OK, and to pay for those higher wages they raise prices for whatever they sell.
There you go - inflation.
It's a self-fulfilling prophecy.
Volcker stuck to his guns, limited the amount of money in the economy.
And by the end of 1981, inflation finally began to drop - 9 percent, then 6 percent, 4 percent.
Bill Silber at NYU says most economists regard Volcker as a hero.
But there are things people wonder about.
There are people who say you didn't have to really put the screws to the economy the way you did.
You could have done it more slowly.
What do you say to that, that maybe it could have been done more gently, without as much pain?
